official-title.#text:
To require the Administrator of the Environmental
		  Protection Agency to withdraw the proposed order published in the January 19,
		  2011, Federal Register (76 Fed. Reg. 3422) pertaining to the pesticide sulfuryl
		  fluoride.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following bill; which was referred
			 to the

text.#text: The Act may be cited as the

The food and fiber
			 supply in the United States is the safest and most abundant and affordable
			 bounty in the world due to efficient application of science-based technologies
			 through the Nation’s enduring heritage of farming and ranching.

Sulfuryl fluoride
			 was tested and found to be a safe and viable broad-spectrum post-harvest
			 alternative to methyl bromide.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
presented the maker of sulfuryl fluoride with a Stratospheric Ozone Protection
			 Award.

text.#text:
Sulfuryl fluoride
			 has evolved into the industry standard and is critical to elimination of pest
			 contamination on foods and further processed food products derived from
			 peanuts, cotton seed, cocoa beans, wheat, rice, corn, oats, oilseeds, nuts,
			 dried fruits, and many agricultural commodities.

Sulfuryl fluoride
			 is also an important fumigant to control pests in various food and agricultural
			 processing facilities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
published in the Federal Register a proposed order to revoke the
			 previously approved food uses for the fumigant sulfuryl fluoride.

issued the
			 proposed order not because it would have any meaningful effect on public
			 health, but because of the presence of excessively high levels of naturally
			 occurring fluoride in certain drinking water systems.

quote.#text:
the
			 elimination of sulfuryl fluoride does not solve, or even significantly
			 decrease, the fluoride … exposure problems

text.#text:
Sulfuryl fluoride is the smallest
			 contributor to total fluoride exposure, and even

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has
			 stated that, if sulfuryl fluoride is

quote.#text:
phased-out from use, industry will
			 be left with few viable sanitation alternatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall withdraw the proposed order published
			 in the January 19, 2011, Federal Register (76 Fed. Reg. 3422) pertaining to the
			 pesticide sulfuryl fluoride.
